message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden appearance of painful ulcers with erythematous base and inguinal lymphadenopathy suggest Herpes simplex virus. Human papillomavirus usually causes warts, while Treponema pallidum and Haemophilus ducreyi are more commonly associated with syphilis and chancroid, respectively.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of painful ulcers on the penis with inguinal lymphadenopathy suggests an acute infection caused by Herpes simplex virus. It is important to note that the patient’s sexual history and inconsistent condom use also suggest an increased risk for sexually transmitted infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden appearance of painful ulcers points to herpes simplex virus, which can also cause inguinal lymphadenopathy. Treponema pallidum, the causative agent of syphilis, can also cause genital ulcers but they typically appear as a single, painless, indurated ulcer. Haemophilus ducreyi causes chancroid, which presents with painful ulcers and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy, but it is rare outside of developing countries. Human papillomavirus can cause genital warts but they do not typically present as painful ulcers.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of painful ulcers and inguinal lymphadenopathy suggests an acute herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection. Human papillomavirus generally presents as warts, not ulcers. Treponema pallidum causes syphilis, which presents with a painless ulcer. Haemophilus ducreyi causes chancroid, which is characterized by a painful ulcer with ragged borders and a purulent base.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of painful ulcers on the penis and significant inguinal lymphadenopathy indicates a sexually transmitted infection. Among the options, Herpes simplex virus is the most likely cause, as it commonly presents with painful, shallow ulcers and inguinal lymphadenopathy. Treponema pallidum can cause syphilis, which presents as painless ulcers with no inguinal lymphadenopathy. Haemophilus ducreyi can cause chancroid, which presents with painful ulcers, but there is usually no significant inguinal lymphadenopathy. Human papillomavirus can cause genital warts but these usually do not present as ulcers.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset and the presence of painful ulcers and inguinal lymphadenopathy suggest genital herpes, caused by herpes simplex virus. Haemophilus ducreyi can also cause painful genital ulcers, but it usually presents as a single ulcer rather than multiple ones. Syphilis caused by Treponema pallidum typically presents as a painless ulcer with no lymphadenopathy. Human papillomavirus can cause genital warts but not painful ulcers.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden appearance of painful ulcers on the penis and significant inguinal lymphadenopathy suggests herpes simplex virus as the most likely etiologic agent. Haemophilus ducreyi can also cause painful genital ulcers, but it usually presents with a papule that progresses to an ulcer with a characteristic "beefy red" base. Treponema pallidum causes painless genital ulcers, and human papillomavirus causes genital warts, not ulcers.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden appearance of multiple painful ulcers with inguinal lymphadenopathy suggests genital herpes, caused by the herpes simplex virus. Haemophilus ducreyi can cause chancroid, but the ulcers are usually larger and more painful. Syphilis caused by Treponema pallidum can also cause genital ulcers, but they are usually single and painless. Human papillomavirus can cause genital warts, but they are not typically painful ulcers.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden appearance of multiple painful ulcers with inguinal lymphadenopathy suggests genital herpes caused by the Herpes simplex virus. The other options may cause genital ulcers, but do not typically present with sudden onset and painful ulcers.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of multiple painful ulcers with inguinal lymphadenopathy suggests herpes simplex virus as the most likely etiologic agent. Human papillomavirus usually presents with warts, Treponema pallidum presents with a painless lesion, and Haemophilus ducreyi presents with a painful papule that develops into an ulcer.
